data.title: Alumni Class Notes
data.text:
Jeffrey Garfinkle 90L is the 2024-2025 president of the Financial Lawyers Conference, a group founded more than 50 years ago that is comprised of leading Southern California commercial finance and insolvency attorneys.

For the past 21 years, he’s practiced with Buchalter in Orange County, California, where he’s a shareholder. He’s among the nation’s leading pharmaceutical and healthcare insolvency attorneys, as evidenced by his 2024 inclusion in Chambers and Partners and Best Lawyers in America.

Thomas S. Cargill 05L has joined Shutts & Bowen as a partner in the firm’s Business Litigation Practice Group. He's based in the Orlando office.

“Tom’s depth of experience as lead counsel in a broad spectrum of business litigation matters makes him an ideal addition to our team,” said Senior Litigation Partner Bud Bennington. “We are excited to welcome him to the Orlando office and we know he will truly be an asset for our clients.” Read the firm release.

Sarah Powell 13L has been promoted to co-chair of Florio Perrucci Steinhardt Cappelli & Tipton’s Corporate & Business, Commercial Real Estate, and Cannabis Practice Groups. She practices in the firm’s Easton, Pennsylvania, offices.

“Sarah is a smart, practical, and hardworking attorney who consistently prioritizes our clients' interests, and works to find creative solutions to the difficult problems that arise in our transactions,” said Practice Group Chair Seth Tipton. “Her willingness to help and mentor our younger attorneys is also invaluable. I am grateful to have Sarah’s expertise and assistance in leading our growing practice groups.” Read the firm release.

Tanisha Palvia 11L, a litigation member at Charlotte’s Moore & Van Allen, PLLC, was named a 2024 South Asian Bar Association (SABA) North America Rising Star. The award celebrates high achievement in practice, innovation, leadership, legal and community service, and commitment to diversity and inclusion. Honorees are under 40, or have been in practice less than 10 years. In July, Palvia received the award at the annual SABA North America Conference in Toronto.

“I can think of no more deserving candidate than Tanisha and we are thrilled to celebrate this distinction,” said the firm’s Diversity Committee Co-chair Valecia M. McDowell. “In addition to serving our clients with remarkable skill, integrity, and compassion, Tanisha has advanced our diversity efforts — especially as a voice for the South Asian legal community — and taken great initiative with mentorship and client development.” Read the firm release.

Funding Florida Legal Aid (formerly the Florida Bar Foundation) has appointed Douglas H. Reynolds 82L 86L to its board of directors for a three-year term beginning July 1, 2024.

Reynolds is a litigation director with Tripp Scott, PA, in Fort Lauderdale. Board-certified by the Florida Bar in both business litigation and marital and family Law, Reynolds served for six years on its Marital and Family Law Certification Committee. He is also on the board of directors of Legal Aid Service of Broward and Collier Counties and Coast to Coast Legal Aid of South Florida. Read the news release.

Otobong “Oto” Ekpo 09L has joined Finch McCranie in Atlanta as of counsel after 15 years as a prosecutor in both DeKalb and Fulton Counties, where she oversaw the most serious crimes. At Fitch, she will focus on representing clients catastrophically injured or killed due to negligence.

“Oto has devoted her career to advocating for victims of wrongdoing,” said Richard Hendrix, a partner with Finch McCranie. “We are proud to add her high-caliber experience to our practice.”

“I consider it a privilege to walk with victims and their loved ones as they pursue justice,” Ekpo said. “While serving victims of crime by putting away the criminals who wronged them has been incredibly rewarding, the move to private practice will enable me to continue to support victims of misconduct in a capacity not before possible.” Read the firm release.

Shannon N. Proctor 15L has been promoted to partner at DC-based litigation firm Hollingsworth LLP. She brings more than a decade’s experience in the pharmaceutical industry to her practice defending Fortune 500 companies in pharmaceutical products liability/personal injury litigation in both federal and state courts across the country. She leads the Women Attorneys of Hollingsworth community group and the firm’s Making Justice Real campaign to support Legal Aid DC.

“Shannon is an expert trial lawyer with a strong track record of representing our clients in complex, high-stakes litigation,” said Hollingsworth LLP Managing Partner Don McMinn. “We are grateful for her expertise and leadership and welcome her to the role of partner.” Read the firm release.

In March, Philip Bauer 96L was named general counsel/corporate secretary at Scientific Games, where he started as a staff attorney in 1999. “It all happened in the blink of an eye,” he writes.

“Since joining Scientific Games in 2022, I have witnessed the strong work we do for our government partners which in turn enables them to serve their taxpayers and residents to provide meaningful programs across all service sectors. In my new position, our goal will be to maximize our services to the benefit of these constituencies,” said EVP James. D. Schultz. “Phil Bauer is a trusted legal advisor with in-depth industry knowledge and will serve us well as we continue to grow our business.” Read the press release.

Emory University’s Office of Global Strategy and Initiatives (GSI) hosted the International Awards at Convocation Hall on Feb. 29 to honor three remarkable members of the Emory community whose endeavors have significantly propelled the university’s global engagement efforts. Faizat Badmus-Busari 20L received the Sheth Distinguished International Alumni Award (Strategic Initiative for Women in the Horn of Africa [SIHA] Network).

“For nearly 25 years, the International Awards have honored individuals who have significantly shaped our university’s global footprint,” says Philip Wainwright, vice provost of GSI. “As a renowned institution with a significant presence on the global stage, it is vital to recognize the diverse endeavors of those who contribute to Emory’s international accomplishments.” Read the news release.

Keith Shapiro, renowned for his leadership and commitment to the Chicagoland Jewish community and Israel, has been named chair of the 2024 JUF Annual Campaign, which is the cornerstone of JUF's multi-faceted resource development efforts, fueling life-transforming services for 500,000 Chicagoans of all faiths and two million Jews across the globe.

“Keith’s commitment to the Jewish people and Israel run deep,” said JUF President Lonnie Nasatir. “He brings great passion, along with tremendous expertise and energy, to this pivotal role, and we are fortunate to have him at the helm of the Campaign.” Read the press release.

Paula Nagarajan 10L is a new partner at Arnall Golden Gregory LLP ‘s Technology and Corporate & Finance practices in Atlanta. She is part of a group working to launch a Women in Technology affinity group due to the number of women attorneys at the firm who work in or around technology. They represent clients worldwide in digital transformations, enterprise-wide technology solutions, data privacy compliance, cyberbreach response, and digital health.

“We are thrilled to welcome Paula to a talented tech-facing group that has continued to grow over the past several years,” said Jacqueline W. Cooney, AGG Privacy & Cybersecurity co-chair. “As we began to assess the capabilities in the firm and the attorneys serving clients in this space, we quickly realized we had something special, and the idea for the affinity group was born.” Read the firm release.

Effective January 1, Jeffrey Thiede 00L is one of 27 new partners at Faegre Drinker. The new cohort hails from 11 firm offices and 13 practice groups. Thiede focuses on real estate and practices in the firm’s Minneapolis office.

“We are thrilled to celebrate this talented group of new partners and counsel. These exceptional individuals bring a commitment to excellence and a spirit of true partnership that strengthen our firm,” Faegre Drinker Chair Gina Kastel said. “We look forward to seeing the contributions they will make to our clients and communities in the years ahead.” Read the firm release.

Congressman Sanford D. Bishop Jr. 71L, a senior member of the US House Appropriations Committee, has been appointed to the Board of Visitors for the United States Military Academy at West Point.

“It is an honor to be selected to serve on the West Point Board of Visitors. I will do my utmost – working with my colleagues on the board – to uphold and support this institution’s morale, discipline, and academic excellence, as well as assure sound curriculum, instruction, equipment, and the fiscal well-being of this vital institution,” Bishop said. “West Point has produced generations of the highest quality of US Army military leaders in the world for over two centuries, and we must do whatever is required to continue that great legacy.” Read the news release.

As of November, Karime Barry 06L is one of 30 new shareholders nationwide at Polsinelli. Barry is in the firm’s Atlanta offices, where she focuses on real estate matters.

“Congratulations to all our new shareholders for achieving this deserved promotion. These outstanding attorneys have demonstrated their extraordinary commitment to client service and greatly contributed to what makes Polsinelli such a thriving firm,” said Polsinelli Chairman and CEO Chase Simmons. “Polsinelli is fortunate to have such exceptional talent, and we are proud to continue to create a firm where all can thrive and where such a high number of women is represented.”

Gary Feldon 07L was one of two attorneys elected new partners at Hollingsworth LLP this August. He’s a litigator in the Washington, DC, office who focuses on Complex Litigation, Pharmaceutical Products, Toxic Torts and Products Liability.

According to the firm: “Gary pairs high-level legal analysis with creative problem solving to achieve the best results for his clients. He often draws on his extensive government experience to help clients resolve complicated legal problems. Recently, he was part of the trial team that secured a complete defense verdict in a 28-day bellwether jury trial in the Circuit Court for Cook County, Ill., relating to ethylene oxide emitted from a medical device sterilization facility.” Read the firm release.

Steven R. Block 80L has joined Blank Rome LLP as co-chair of the firm’s new Dallas office. He is a partner in the firm's Corporate, M&A, and Securities Group.

“There is a remarkable alignment among the six partners who are launching Blank Rome in Dallas,” Block said. “Each of us was seeking an opportunity to expand our practices on a national platform with comprehensive service offerings to better serve our clients. And to be able to do this while opening a new office for Blank Rome in a city that we all love is an incredible opportunity.” Read the firm release.

Jim Cohen 79L wrote the book Modern Judaica: Today's Makers, Today's Sacred Objects during the pandemic. It was published by Schiffer Publishing in February 2023. Cohen says it reflects interviews he conducted with more than 50 Judaica makers from around the world and includes over 250 color images of their work.

“The book allows the makers to tell their story as to why they make Judaica and its importance to them,” Cohen says, adding that he is long retired from practicing law and lives in Durham, NC. The book is available through book retailers, online, or directly thorough Cohen.

John C. Sammon 74C 77L received the Georgia State Bar’s 2023 Distinguished Service Award, which was presented during the Bar’s annual meeting on June 10, 2023. He was honored for 46 years of service, including 10 years as a member of the Board of Governors and Executive Committee of the State Bar of Georgia. Sammon was elected as the youngest president of the State Bar of Georgia in 1993.

“John Sammon has distinguished himself as a private practice attorney, as well as through his stellar record of leadership and service to the legal profession,” said Bar President Sarah B. “Sally” Akins. “The legal community in our state owes considerable appreciation to John for his exemplary commitment, integrity and leadership in service to the legal profession, the justice system and the state of Georgia.” Read the Gwinnett Daily Post story.

Michael J. Abrams 91L joined fellow Lathrop GPM LLP partners at a recent groundbreaking for Kansas City’s Rock Island Bridge project, which will create what organizers say is America’s first entertainment district on a bridge. It’s scheduled to open in spring 2024.

"It’s been an honor to work on this project alongside my talented Lathrop GPM colleagues," said Abrams, who hammered in a golden spike at the ceremony. "This bridge helped build the Kansas City economy during its time as a railroad and will now continue to do so for future generations." A Lathrop GPM team negotiated contracts, assisted with platting and title work, and laid the groundwork for $5.5 million in private investments. The project been invited to join the High Line Network, a working think tank for US infrastructure reuse projects. Read the firm release.

On June 9, 2023, former Volunteer Clinic for Veterans Senior Staff Attorney Carlissa Carson 08L received the Georgia State Bar’s Marshall-Tuttle Award, which honors lawyers who work on behalf of Georgia’s more than 700,000 veterans. Carson was recognized for helping veterans with civil matters, which can make a profound difference for those who were injured during their service and are seeking VA disability benefits from the Veterans Benefits Administration. She received the award at the State Bar’s annual meeting in Savannah.

“As someone who has served in both the Army and Air Force, I understand how difficult it is for veterans to navigate the invisible ice of the VA system,” Carson said. “It is an honor and a pleasure to serve military veterans, helping them break down barriers to benefits.” Read more.

Dean R. Fuchs 94L was recently honored by the Pro Bono Partnership of Atlanta as one of its six 2022 Volunteers of the Year. The PBPA provides free legal services to community-based nonprofits that operate programs benefitting low-income or disadvantaged individuals.

“While it’s always nice to be recognized as a volunteer, I’m certain I have gotten much more out of my work with the Pro Bono Partnership than they have from me,” Fuchs said. “I look forward to continuing my small role in helping exceptional nonprofits that are dedicated to assisting valuable members of our community to achieve their personal and professional goals.” Fuchs is a partner with Schulten Ward Turner & Weiss, LLP. Read the news release.

Steve Karcher 88L writes that while he’s inactive as an attorney, he is now a rector for an Episcopal parish in Colorado. “My legal training and decades of both state and federal litigation continue to beneficially impact both me and the community I serve,” he says. Following busy and fulfilling practice in California, Nebraska, and Iowa, Karcher earned an MDiv and was ordained as an Episcopal priest in 2017. He and his wife have two daughters: one is a paralegal in Maryland, and the other is pursuing a PhD. “Thank you, Emory, for getting me on the road to two fine service careers!” he writes.

Fair Trials has partnered with Belmont University College of Law Professor Lucian E. Dervan 02L to launch the Plea Bargaining Institute, designed to create a global intellectual home for academics, policymakers, advocacy organizations, and practitioners working in the plea bargaining space. In the US, 95% or more of criminal cases are resolved through a plea of guilty.

“The institute will help make plea bargaining research findings and case developments widely available to those in the field, while simultaneously creating a space for dialogue and collaboration to assist in identifying new areas of research and inquiry to help propel reform efforts,” Dervan writes. Read more.

In April, David Zalesne 87L will receive the Robert P. Stupp Award for Leadership Excellence, the American Institute of Steel Construction’s highest industry honor. Zalesne is president of Owen Steel Company and a former chair of the institute’s board of directors.

“David is a visionary who sees opportunities and solutions the rest of us can't. Even better, he's wonderfully able to share his vision and engage the rest of us,” said AISC President Charles J. Carter. “David commits and always builds great outcomes.” Zalesne is only the 10th Stupp Award winner since the program’s inception in 1998. Prior to becoming president of Owen Steel Company in 2004, Zalesne was a partner in the Litigation Department of Klehr, Harrison in Philadelphia and also worked as an assistant U.S. attorney in the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. Read more.

Rhani Lott Choi 10L has joined the National Institute for Trial Advocacy (NITA) as education director, effective June 1, 2022. In this newly created leadership position, Choi will oversee faculty recruitment, faculty training and development, and curriculum design.

“NITA has been a huge part of my professional life for over a decade, and the best part of that experience has been working with NITA’s world-class faculty,” Choi said. “I’m excited to join the rest of the team at NITA Central and to use my experience and education to support the faculty and further the mission of NITA.” Read more.

Leah Ward Sears 80L has been voted the best mediator/arbitrator by lawyers and law firm administrators who read the Daily Report. Also, the former Georgia Supreme Court Chief Justice’s firm, Alterity ADR, an Atlanta-based alternative dispute resolution firm founded in August 2021, was named “best of” in its category.

"The qualities of a good judge are to judge, and I thought I was a pretty good judge. But those are not the qualities of a good mediator,” Sears said. “A good mediator has to be able to take the lawyers' view of their cases and test whether, in their eyes as well as those of their clients, those evaluations make sense logically, feel right emotionally, and are doable practically. It pleases me that many believe I was able to master both very different skill sets during my legal career. Thank you for this recognition." Read the firm release.

In May, Lynn Greenky 82L's book, When Freedom Speaks: The Boundaries and the Boundlessness of our First Amendment Right was published by Brandeis University Press. She’s an associate teaching professor at Syracuse University.

“Greenky maps the history of the First Amendment’s free speech clause from its foundation and building blocks to contemporary controversies,” one review reads. “In 15 chapters, she lays out types of speech—protected and unprotected, symbolic, political, offensive, harmful, and hate—that have posed significant complications. She also considers problematic issues such as speech in public schools and other public places, the right to speak through silence, and both sides of the battle to speak, shout, protest, or counsel about abortion.” Visit her website.

Congratulations to Chad F. Slieper 05L, director of the Law, Science, and Technology program at Georgia Tech’s Ivan Allen College of Liberal Arts School of Public Policy. He received an Academic Faculty Distinguished Teaching Award during the college’s year-end awards ceremony.

“Of the various components of my job, teaching is the absolute most important, gratifying, and let’s be honest, FUN thing I get to do!,” Slieper posted on LinkedIn. “I graduated from the Georgia Institute of Technology 20 years ago this spring. When I was walking to my car from my last final exam in 2002, I remember telling my mom on the phone that I felt like my work at Tech wasn’t done. Little did I know what was in store two decades down the line.” Read the post.

As part of the expansion of its Atlanta office, Parker Poe hired 16 new education attorneys including Associate MaryGrace Bell Kitrell 14L and Partner Cheryl Shaw 84C 90L. “Each member of our team has a personal connection to the work that we do, and we recognize that K-12 and higher education is not just an industry but a civic good that is critical to a functioning, healthy democracy,” said Partner Nina Gupta. “We take the responsibility seriously and are honored to partner with our clients to ensure the availability of a high-quality education for future generations.” Read the firm release.

As of January 2021, Diane Melnick 91L is a partner in Practus LLP’s Intellectual Property Group. She is based in New York City. “I've experienced government service (at the United States Patent and Trademark Office), in-house practice at multinational corporate giants and startups, and the joys of private practice in both large and small firms,” she writes. “The journey has been full of learning and growing, but I am happy to be settled into a firm where I can collaborate with great colleagues and also make my own decisions about client management.”

Katherine Silverman 11L and William Piercy 97L represented the Love Renaissance record label and its founders in a business divorce case that was covered by among others, Rolling Stone. The Atlanta label works with hip-hop and R&B artists including Shelley (f/k/a D.R.A.M.) 6lack and Summer Walker.

“After a five-day trial consisting of eight witnesses, more than 30 exhibits and three hours of deliberation, the jury awarded LVRN $50,000 against the consultants and awarded the consultants $3,463.27 in connection with certain tax withholdings. In that LVRN went to trial facing the possibility of a multi-million-dollar verdict against it, this was a huge win,” according to the firm’s blog. Read the blog post.

Gregory W. Dewan 10L has been named executive director, president, and CEO of the Frank H. Hiscock Legal Aid Society in Syracuse, New York, effective February 1, 2022. The society has approximately 75 full-time staff and provides free legal services to low-income residents of Central New York, including immigration, divorce, domestic violence, family law, housing, unemployment insurance, appeals, and parole revocation cases.

“I am humbled and excited by the opportunity to serve as the next Executive Director of the Hiscock Legal Aid Society,” Dewan said. “As a lifelong resident of Central New York, it is particularly rewarding to be leading an organization I believe in, alongside people I believe in, to fulfill a critical mission ensuring access to justice for all in our community.” Read the news release.

Ilene W. Berman 90L and Brian T. Nash 87L are among the dozen attorneys who launched Continuum Legal Group LLP this October in Atlanta. The firm’s primary areas of practice are commercial litigation, corporate, employment, environmental, lending and real estate. Nash’s specialties are corporate and technology law, and Berman focuses on employment and employment litigation.

“We’ve been colleagues and friends for years – in fact, decades for a number of us - so the idea of a ‘continuum’ resonated strongly,” said Founding Partner Marc D. Glenn. “We’re comfortable working together, and we have an immense level of trust in each other, knowing that any of us who work on a client’s file will bring a tremendous level of expertise, service and practicality to the matter. Berman adds: “if you look up the word continuum, one meaning is ‘a coherent whole characterized as a collection,’ which aptly describes our new law firm. It’s that cohesiveness that enhances the type of service we give to our clients.” Read the firm release.

Michael Fabius 07L is one of 13 new Ballard Spahr lawyers admitted to partnership, effective July 1. He is co-practice leader of the Gaming Group and practices in the firm’s Philadelphia offices, where he advises clients in the highly regulated gaming and racing industries, and in litigation before administrative agencies.

“Our new partners are consummate professionals with top-flight legal acumen and sound business knowledge, a combination of attributes that has enabled them to build indispensable partnerships that help the firm’s clients succeed,” said firm Chair Mark Stewart. “Their elevation to our partnership is well-deserved, and we are proud to welcome them.” Read the firm release.

Alyson Pirio 05C 08L has joined Troutman Pepper as a partner in the firm’s Tax & Benefits Practice Group. Previously, she was senior corporate counsel for GSMA, Ltd., where she was responsible for managing the trade association’s corporate governance, contracting, and tax compliance activities. She also served in the Office of Chief Counsel in the Internal Revenue Service’s Atlanta office.

“Aly brings highly valuable skills and experience to our practice,” said Joan Arnold, leader of the firm’s Tax & Benefits Practice Group. “Her sophisticated nonprofit tax experience and tax work in the partnership and transactional arenas is a big draw for the firm and allows us to provide even more robust services for our clients.”

David L. Ladov 78L will receive the 2021 Pennsylvania Bar Association Family Law Section Eric Turner Memorial Award during the section’s virtual summer meeting, July 15-16. The award honors a lawyer who is dedicated to the practice of family law and who serves as a mentor and teacher to fellow lawyers. He is a partner in Obermayer Law’s West Conshohocken offices.

“Ladov has more than 40 years of experience in family law matters, including divorce, complex equitable distribution matters, custody cases, spousal support cases and protection from abuse matters for abused children and spouses. As the chair of his firm’s family law practice, he draws from his diverse experience to help clients better understand and handle their own unique personal situations,” according to the Bar Association. Read the news release.

LaShawn A. Oxendine 13L has joined Norris McLaughlin, P.A., as an associate in the firm’s Times Square, New York City, office. She’s a member of the Taxation Practice Group, and focuses on tax law, negotiating tax representations, warranties, covenants, and other key tax provisions of various transaction agreements.

“With LaShawn on board, we are expanding our team of taxation attorneys into New York to better serve our clients and their needs, and further enhance our reach. With her experience, LaShawn will be a valuable asset not only to the group and the New York office but to the entire firm,” said Andrew N. Parfomak, administrative partner. Read the firm release.

In May, Carlos Kelly 97L was named new chair of Henderson, Franklin, Starnes & Holt, P.A.’s Business Litigation Department. Kelly joined the Fort Myers, Florida, firm in 1997.

“I have had the honor and privilege of working extensively with Carlos for nearly 25 years. I have watched him grow and become an outstanding lawyer,” said Managing Stockholder Douglas Szabo. “He is bright, detail-oriented, and driven to do his best for his clients. I have no doubt these same skills and traits will serve him, the firm, and the Business Litigation Department in his new role as chair.” Read the firm release.

Terry Weiss 86L has joined Maynard Cooper & Gale as a shareholder to lead the firm’s newly established Atlanta office. Weiss’ focus is on representing the securities industry in the full range of legal disputes. In the enforcement arena, he works with and litigates against securities industry regulators, including the SEC, FINRA, and state regulators, among others. He’s served as lead counsel in over 100 arbitrations through award and has supervised hundreds of others, including appellate matters.

“Terry is a highly respected attorney in his field and mirrors our client-centered service approach,” said Jeff Grantham, Maynard’s managing shareholder. “We look forward to the impact he will have on our expanding Securities Practice and Firm.” Read the firm release.

Roy Richter 11L is one of nine associates at Winstead PC recently promoted to Of Counsel. He is a member of the firm’s Corporate, Securities/Mergers & Acquisitions Practice Group in The Woodlands, Texas, where he focuses on general corporate and securities representation and business counseling of public and private corporations. As a former landman, Richter has experience in both the legal and oil and gas industries.

“We congratulate these nine talented attorneys on being named Of Counsel,” Winstead CEO David Dawson said. “These are attorneys with outstanding experience who have been incredibly valuable members of our team.”

David Topping 12L is one of five new partners at Phelps in New Orleans, where he focuses on transactional support, regulatory compliance and litigation. As a litigator, he “lowers clients’ legal risks through environmental due diligence. Clients look to his litigation experience and industry knowledge to keep them above board with environmental regulators.”

“Each of these attorneys has built a strong track record of helping clients,” said Managing Partner Marshall Redmon. “This group will add mightily to the firm’s ability to secure legal solutions for clients and offer them the wraparound, personal service our firm is known for.”

Alexandra “Sachi” Cole 11L has been named partner at Penn Law LLC in Atlanta. Since joining the firm in 2017, she has been instrumental in cases involving the Boy Scouts of America, Amazon and the Catholic Church. She specializes in complex civil litigation focusing on cases involving product liability, medical malpractice, childhood sexual abuse and employment law. She also worked on important legislation including the Child Victim Act.

“We are proud to name Sachi Cole as a partner at Penn Law, in recognition of the work she has done, and what she will bring to our team moving forward,” says the firm’s founder, Darren Penn. Read the firm release.

Deidré Keller 06L was named dean of Florida A & M University College of Law in Orlando this spring and begins work in July. Prior to that, she was associate dean of the Claude W. Pettit College of Law at Ohio Northern University. A native of Georgetown, Guyana, Keller grew up in the Bronx, New York. In addition to her JD earned at Emory Law, Keller also holds a Bachelor of Arts in English and Sociology from Yale University.

“Keller’s stellar academic credentials and diverse set of professional experiences in the legal and academic fields made her an ideal candidate for this position,” said Maurice Edington, provost and vice president for Academic Affairs. “She has articulated a clear and ambitious vision for the College, and I am confident that she will provide strong, dynamic and transformational leadership as the next dean.”

Stephen Alicanti 12L 12B was promoted to partner on April 1, 2020. A corporate and securities lawyer at DLA Piper in New York City, Alicanti focuses on representing issuers and underwriters in domestic and international capital markets transactions.

"We have a strong pipeline of talent and nurturing and promoting our people is central to our values and strategy of providing the best client service,” said Simon Levine, Global Co-CEO. “These accomplished new partners have shown that embracing radical change and being a trusted business adviser is at the heart of our commitment to clients, and I would like to congratulate all of them on their promotions." Read the firm release.

Maria Saltiero Doughty 88C 92L is the new president and CEO of The Chicago Network, which represents more than 500 of the city’s “most influential women leaders at the forefront of Chicago’s business, professional, cultural, nonprofit and educational organizations.” Her term starts April 6. Doughty spent 23 years at Allstate Insurance Co. in senior legal, public policy, governmental affairs, and community relations positions, and led the company’s global efforts to create senior leadership opportunities for women.

“We are thrilled to welcome Maria as our next leader,” said Diane Offereins, chair of The Chicago Network and Executive Vice President, President, Payment Services at Discover Financial Services. “Maria’s strategic leadership, policy experience, and lifetime passion for promoting gender equity are exactly the characteristics required to take The Chicago Network to the next level.” Read the press release.

Berman Fink Van Horn ( BFV) was ranked the sixth fastest-growing law firm (by revenue) in the 2020 Atlanta Business Chronicle Annual Book of Lists. The business law firm was founded by Jeffrey Berman 82L, Benjamin Fink 92L and Charles Van Horn 94L and has a strong roster of Emory Law alumni, including: William Piercy 97L, Neal Weinrich 06L, Lauren Simons Frisch 13L, Katherine Silverman 11L, Alan Lubel 75L, Lisa Morchower 89L and Lydia Hilton 87L. Several alumni were recently recognized by Super Lawyers for excellence in their fields:

2020 Georgia Super Lawyer*

Benjamin I. Fink 92L (Top 100) – Business Litigation

Alan E. Lubel 75L – Business Litigation

William J. Piercy 97L – Business Litigation

Charles H. Van Horn 94L – Business Litigation

*No more than 5 percent of the Georgia lawyers are selected

2020 Rising Stars*

Lauren S. Frisch 13L – Business Litigation

Katherine Silverman 11L – Civil Litigation: Plaintiff

Neal F. Weinrich 06L – Business Litigation

*Attorneys 40 and under or in practice for 10 years or less (no more than 2.5 percent of Georgia lawyers)

Shareholders Berman, Fink and Van Horn were also included on the 2020 “Best Lawyers in America” list. Berman was recognized for mergers and acquisitions; Fink for labor and employment and employment law; and Van Horn for commercial litigation, real estate litigation and construction litigation. Read the firm release.

Lynsey Barron 09L has joined Miller & Martin, PLLC, in Atlanta as a member in its litigation department. She previously served as a federal prosecutor with the U.S. Attorney’s Office in Atlanta, in the Economic Fraud and Public Corruption sections. Immediately prior to joining Miller & Martin, she was as in-house compliance, data privacy, and cybersecurity counsel with UPS.

“Lynsey’s body of work is very impressive, and we are thrilled to add her to our white collar and government investigations practice. Particularly as she pursues certification as a Certified Information Privacy Professional, we know she will be a tremendous resource to clients as part of our Privacy and Data Security team as well,” said Michael Kohler, chair of the firm’s litigation department.

Oderah C. Nwaeze 11L has been promoted to partner at Duane Morris LLP. As a trial lawyer in the firm’s Wilmington, Delaware, offices, he litigates complex corporate and commercial matters involving state and federal law. That includes corporate governance actions; statutory actions arising under Delaware corporation law; state and federal class actions; and breach of contract disputes. Working with the firm’s IP Practice Group, he also represents clients in patent and copyright litigation in U.S. District Court. Nwaeze serves on the Compliance Committee of the board of trustees for Bancroft, a nonprofit provider of specialized services for individuals with brain injuries, autism and intellectual disabilities. He is also on the board of directors for Campus Philly, which aims to fuel economic growth in Philadelphia by encouraging college students to live and work in the Philadelphia region.

In January, Luther J. Battiste III was installed as national president of the American Board of Trial Advocates at the organization’s National Board Meeting. Battiste, a founding shareholder of Johnson, Toal & Battiste, P.A., took the oath of office from retired Chief Justice Jean Hoefer Toal of the Supreme Court of South Carolina. Battiste is the first African American to serve as national president. He also made history in 1983 by becoming one of the first two African Americans elected to Columbia City Council since Reconstruction. He served 15 years as a member of the Columbia City Council, including two terms as Mayor Pro Tempore. Read the release.

In January, Rainbow Willard 10L was promoted to counsel at Chaffetz Lindsey. Willard regularly appears before international arbitration tribunals and U.S. courts in complex, cross-border matters. She has also helped several clients navigate parallel proceedings in international arbitration and national courts in a host of foreign jurisdictions. Willard is fluent in English, Spanish, and Kaqchikel Maya. A former federal public defender, Willard joined the firm in 2017, from Allen & Overy LLP, where she was a senior associate who practice in London and New York.

“Rainbow has played a leading role in some of our most complex arbitration matters,” said Aníbal Sabater, a member of the firm’s management group. “We could not be more impressed with her intelligence and judgment." Read more.

Priya B. Vivian 04C 09L has been elected a shareholder at Lane Powell, where she is an employment advisor and litigator who counsels employers on the full employment cycle including hiring, employment contracts, disability accommodation, handbooks and policies, discipline and separations. She also provides on-site training to employees regarding state and federal employment law compliance and represents employers in disputes, either before the EEOC or a local agency, or in federal or state litigation. In 2019, Thomson Reuters named her a “Rising Star” in labor and employment. She serves on the board of both the Mother Attorneys Mentoring Association of Seattle and Emory Law’s Alumni Association. She joined Lane Powell’s Seattle office in 2016 as an associate.

Christopher C. Bly 99C 02L celebrates a year on the federal bench this month, as a United States District Court magistrate for Georgia’s Northern District. When announcing his selection, Chief U.S. District Judge Thomas W. Thrash Jr. cited Bly’s academic and professional record.

“Chris has an exceptional scholastic record in both his undergraduate and law school studies at Emory University, including serving as the managing editor for the Emory Law Journal. His professional experience includes practice in both the private and public sector. Most recently, Chris served as an assistant United States attorney in the Appellate Section of the United States Attorney's Office for the Northern District of Georgia,” Thrash wrote. “Chris is a superb selection to join our exceptional bench of magistrate Judges.” Bly’s chambers are in the Atlanta federal courthouse.

Alison Elko Franklin 03L is a new shareholder at Greenberg Traurig, LLP, as part of the firm’s expansion of its global Restructuring & Bankruptcy Practice. Franklin joins the firm from Dentons, and will advise clients on a broad range of restructuring matters, including corporate reorganizations, municipal reform, creditors’ rights litigation, and distressed acquisitions.

"Alison has a sterling reputation and is highly regarded in the Atlanta bankruptcy community. She will be a valuable addition to our team," said the firm’s David Kurzweil. "With wide-ranging industry experience and a diverse practice, Alison's breadth of knowledge will allow us to further our goal of providing the best service for our clients, both in Atlanta and firmwide." Read the Daily Report story.

Kristin Goran 05L now serves on the board of directors of Goodwill Industries International, the organization announced this month. She is general counsel of Primrose Schools, and previously served on the board of the nonprofit, Camp Kudzu. Goran is also chair of the Franchise and Distribution Law Section of the State Bar of Georgia.

“Kristin has a keen understanding of how a parent organization and a franchisee can work together to build and protect a brand,” said Steven C. Preston, Goodwill International’s president and CEO. “Her perspective will be invaluable to our nonprofit network of 158 independent member organizations dedicated to helping people find jobs and advance their careers.”

Steven Rosenberg 90L is city manager of Staunton, Virginia, as of July 1. He previously served as the city’s deputy manager and has 29 years of city, county and state government experience.

“All of our finalists were very competitive and could bring numerous strengths to the position,” Mayor Carolyn Dull said. “However, it was clear that Steve Rosenberg had the knowledge, skills, and abilities needed to be successful as Staunton’s city manager. Just as important, he loves Staunton and its citizens, and is passionate about our work together.” Read the news release.

In July, JetBlue announced the appointment of Teri P. McClure 88L to its board of directors.

McClure recently retired after nearly 25 years at UPS, where she was chief human resources officer and senior vice president of labor.

“We’re so pleased to welcome Teri to the board with her wealth of experience building high performing teams at one of the nation’s largest employers,” said Joel Peterson, chair of the JetBlue board. “She also brings valuable legal and aviation perspective from across the globe that will support the success of the airline.” McClure’s appointment brings JetBlue’s Board of Directors to 11 members, 10 of whom are independent. Read the release.

“Women lawyers lead the profession in tremendous numbers, but only about 20 percent of equity shareholders at a law firm are women. They don't tend to be the rainmakers,” Julie Fershtman 86L says in a Q & A with Crain’s Detroit Business. “The networking program is for women to share concerns and support and promote each other. Over the last 30 years, just about every law school shows admission criteria for its first year students. Enrollment is made up of 50 percent women. That was true of my class when I went to Emory Law School in 1983.” Read the story.

On June 1, Christine E. Howard 90L started a three-year term on Fisher Phillips’ Management Committee. She is the first woman to serve on the three-member committee, which is considered the equivalent of the board of directors. Fisher Phillips is comprised of 34 offices, with more than 400 lawyers. Howard is managing partner of the firm's Tampa office and a partner in the Atlanta office. She also served as a founding co-chair of the firm's Women's Initiative and Leadership Council.

“Christine is a distinguished lawyer and exemplifies the firm’s commitment to furthering diversity across all ranks. I am confident in her experience and enthusiasm to help lead the firm during this period of rapid growth,” said Managing Partner Roger Quillen. Howard focuses on the defense of employment discrimination, harassment, and retaliation complaints, wage and hour litigation, and employee leave related complaints. Read the release.

On June 5, Rachelle Carnesale 92L was appointed to the Fulton County Superior Court bench by Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp. Carnesale was on the shortlist of three nominees given to Kemp in May by the Georgia Judicial Nominating Commission for consideration to fill a vacancy created by Judge Gail Tusan taking senior status this spring. Carnesale is now Cherokee County chief assistant district attorney.

“Rachelle Carnesale’s experience, temperament, and leadership style are ideal for the Atlanta Judicial Circuit Superior Court,” Kemp said in a statement. “As a successful prosecutor and fierce advocate for our most vulnerable,” she “will lead by example and excel on the bench,” according to the Daily Report. Carnesale has previously served as director of the Division of Family and Children Services, and acting director of the Office of the Child Advocate and deputy chief district attorney in DeKalb County, where she supervised the Crimes Against Children Unit.

Read the story.

With Laurie Speed 99L at the helm, the Georgia Trial Lawyers Association stepped up its presence at the Georgia Legislature this year.

GTLA members “put their own practices on hold to make sure we have a voice at the Capitol and that bad laws are not passed. I think it’s what makes trial lawyers different. This isn’t a job for us,” Speed told the Daily Report in April, when her year as president ended. “We’re a one-issue organization,” she adds. “We’re focused on protecting the right to trial by jury.” Speed will serve on the executive committee for another year as immediate past president, and return her focus to Speed & King, the litigation firm she started with Michelle King two years ago. They specialize in personal injury and medical malpractice. Read the story.

An April 11 fundraiser for the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers’ Foundation for Criminal Justice, “From Legal Aid to Legal Stars: Barry Scheck and David Rudolf” will be hosted by Drew Findling 84L, NACDL president, and his wife, Beth. It’s billed as “an evening with two all-star lawyers and their legal journey from the South Bronx to streaming superstardom.”

“The NFCJ provides critical support for the nation’s criminal defense bar—the constitutionally-ordained guardians of individual liberty,” Findling said. “The criminal defense function is the ultimate brake on governmental power versus the individual, and the NFCJ ensures that the defense bar is robust in defense of the individual and pursuit of criminal justice reform. Whether assuring the government needs a warrant to search a cellphone, advocating for Brady reform, or training and ensuring that everyone has an effective lawyer, the NFCJ is the most important charity I can think of to fix America’s criminal justice system.”

On April 2, President Donald Trump announced he intends to nominate Steven Grimberg 98L for U.S. District Court judge, to serve in Atlanta. Grimberg is a former U.S. attorney known for prosecuting white-collar and cyber crimes, who served with the Department of Justice for more than 12 years. In 2018, he joined Nardello & Co., where he is managing director, head of the Atlanta office, and general counsel of the Americas. Grimberg is also an adjunct professor at Emory Law. A first-generation American, his parents immigrated from Argentina.

“President Trump has made an excellent choice in selecting Steven Grimberg to serve as a judge for the Northern District Court of Georgia,” David Perdue told the Daily Report. “Throughout his extensive legal career as a federal prosecutor, including seven years as an assistant U.S. attorney in Atlanta, Mr. Grimberg has served Georgians and the country with distinction. Steven Grimberg is immensely qualified for this role, and I am delighted to work with him through the confirmation process.” Read the story.

Sharon A. Gay 82L is the 2019 recipient of the WomenLEAD Excellence Award, an honor from her firm, Dentons. It recognizes women who distinguish themselves in advancing female colleagues. Gay received the “Above & Beyond” Award for her efforts to promote and elevate her women colleagues at all stages of their careers. Gay is managing partner of Denton’s Atlanta office and a member of the Public Policy practice. She is actively involved in interviewing, recruiting and integration efforts, and encourages and supports women to aid them in assuming active and visible roles in the office, the firm and the community. Read the firm release.

Leah Ward Sears 80L was quoted in the Daily Report story, “Talent or Token? Lawyers Say Diversity Still Can Be Just for Show.” The headline: “A steady stream of initiatives has scarcely increased the ranks of lawyers of color in Big Law—amid concerns that some are used as ‘window dressing’ for client pitches.”

“We’ve made great strides, but it’s been in baby steps,” Sears said. She was the first black female lawyer at Alston & Bird’s predecessor, Alston Miller & Gaines, and went on to become the youngest-ever Georgia Supreme Court justice. In the ‘80s, “it was pretty obvious that you weren’t going to get the same kind of opportunities that were going to young men who looked like the partners,” she said. “It’s better than just tokenism now,” she said. “But we have not come as far as we need to. It’s not a walk in the park for any minority now at any firm.” Read the story.

Lisa Lott 94L took the bench as Superior Court judge for Georgia’s Western Judicial Circuit on Jan 1. But her election last year was both remarkable and a first.

She was the first woman elected to that bench, but also one of only two judges in the Western Circuit’s 118-year history who won their seat purely by election, rather than first serving as a governor’s appointee. Other than Judge David Sweat’s election in 2002, “the other judges who were appointed retained their seat in subsequent elections,” Lott said. “Although I have to say there were very few challengers throughout that history.”

Last May, Lott won with 54.6 of the vote against Judge Regina Quick, who Gov. Nathan Deal appointed in August 2017. Prior to that, Quick was a Georgia State House representative. Lott, a longtime public defender who lives in Athens, campaigned on the idea that judicial appointees often don’t reflect the cities they serve, she said.

“It is time for our community to elect our judges, as opposed to Atlanta appointing all of our superior court judges … And by Atlanta, I mean the governor,” Lott told the Red & Black.

“I’ve been a public servant in our community for the last 18 years ... I’ve had my feet on the ground, working in this community for those less fortunate,” Lott said during the campaign. “I’ve been involved in this community as a volunteer, as a concerned citizen, and as a parent. I know what makes this community tick. That is perspective which I believe is an essential characteristic for a fair and impartial judge.” The Western Circuit includes Clarke and Oconee Counties. Lott will serve a four-year term.

Christine Norstadt 09L has joined Chamberlain, Hrdlicka, White, Williams & Aughtry as senior counsel. For 18 years, she and Stephanie Friese, who also joined the firm, have advised clients in all phases of commercial development and transactions.

“Stephanie and Christine’s depth of experience is an asset to our growing Atlanta office,” said Managing Shareholder Wayne Risoli. “The strategic expansion of our real estate practice is in response to client needs and is reflective of our commitment to providing integrated services for virtually all legal matters related to real estate transactions and development.”

In 2018, the pair negotiated more than one million square feet of office leases totaling more than $50 million in value. In 2018, they represented Safavieh in the acquisition and development of a 1.6 million square foot distribution center in Savannah and negotiated subsequent industrial leases to Wayfair and Electrolux. Read the firm release.

Baylie Fry 15L was profiled about her life and career at BakerHostetler LLP by VoyageATL. “After passing the Georgia Bar in 2015, am a practicing lawyer focusing my practice on healthcare transactions,” she says. “The process was a tough one, but I can truly say that I would not be where I am today without my support system—my family and friends who have all been there for me to help me through the tough times and celebrate my accomplishments.” Read the story.

The Columbia Museum of Art presented the 2018 John Richard Craft Leadership Award to Luther J. Battiste III 74L. “A community leader, philanthropist, and public servant, Battiste epitomizes the values the CMA recognizes each year with the Craft Award,” according to a press release. Battiste received the award, named for the CMA’s first director, on Nov. 14, 2018.

“Luther Battiste is a positive force in the life of our community, a person distinguished for his balanced and productive leadership and love of the arts,” said Executive Director Della Watkins. “He has happily contributed to the museum’s growth and continuing success and served with modesty as an example for how to strengthen our shared commitment to culture. It is a privilege to recognize Luther for his outstanding service.” Read more

Mystery novelist and former judge Debra H. Goldstein 77L celebrated her new series debut with the release of One Taste Too Many (published by Kensington Books) on Dec. 18, 2018.

Goldstein is an Agatha and Anthony Award finalist, and here’s a synopsis of the book: “It introduces Sarah Blair, a culinary-challenged, recently-divorced woman adjusting to her new status as ‘single,’ her new studio apartment—which she shares with her Siamese cat, RahRah—and her new job as a law firm receptionist. When her ex-husband gets murdered and her twin sister becomes the top suspect, Sarah will have to add ‘solving crimes’ to the list of challenges she’s taking on.”

“The time has come to sail off into the sunset,” Clay Seaman 74L writes. He spent 20 years in the Navy JAG Corps and retired in 1994. His service included forward tours in the eastern Mediterranean and the Persian Gulf. “For the last 20 years or so, I have had something of a niche appellate practice,” he says. “I have only six clients, all of whom live in relatively close proximity in the most exclusive gated community in California--Death Row at San Quentin,” He now lives in Prescott, Arizona, with his wife, Nancy. “Soon, we’ll be able to hike in the western national parks, putter in the garden and play with the dogs. Not bad things to do in retirement.”

Julie Fershtman 83C 86L, equity shareholder with Foster Swift Collins & Smith, received the Michigan Bar’s highest honor at the State Bar’s NEXT Conference and Annual Meeting, held in September in Grand Rapids. The Roberts P. Hudson Award commends “one or more lawyers for their unselfish rendering of outstanding and unique service to and on behalf of the State Bar of Michigan, the legal profession and public.” The award isn’t given annually, but awarded periodically based on merit. Fershtman is co-recipient with Bruce Courtade.

“My father was a lawyer. My husband is a lawyer. It was a commitment I was born into as the daughter of a lawyer who really took his job very seriously,” Fershtman said. “You don’t become a lawyer without a significant and sincere commitment to the public and the people you serve. When you become a lawyer, your commitment is serving your clients and protecting them.”

A book by Carrie Baker 94L, Fighting the US Youth Sex Trade: Gender, Race, and Politics was published in September by Cambridge University Press. “Earlier this year, Congress passed two laws that allow states to criminally prosecute internet service providers who 'promote or facilitate' prostitution of another person and allow individuals to sue internet service providers for civil damages for harm resulting from such actions,” Baker writes on the Cambridge blog. “These laws resulted from the efforts of a politically and ideologically diverse anti-child-sex-trafficking movement that included conservatives and liberals, feminists, evangelical Christians, and others. But despite the broad-based, bipartisan support for these laws, the politics behind them are complicated.” Baker is director of the Program for the Study of Women and Gender at Smith College. Read more

After a half-century practicing law—44 years on the bench, and more than two decades on the Supreme Court of Georgia—Chief Justice P. Harris Hines 68L has written his last opinion. He estimates he's written a thousand. His last day was Aug. 31. “It’s bittersweet leaving,” Hines told the Daily Report. “I’m not one to look back. The practice of law has been good to me. I’m one of those who have always been able to like what they do.” Read the story.

Drew Findling 84L was sworn in as president of the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers at its annual meeting on July 29. He was also the 2018 recipient of NACDL’s Robert C. Heeney Memorial Award, an honor presented annually to the member who best demonstrates the goals and values of the association and of the legal profession.

“Drew Findling’s entire life has been about service and the defense of people against whom the deck is clearly stacked, people who quite literally are oppressed by our criminal justice system” said past president Rick Jones. Findling was sworn by Vernon S. Pitts Jr., who hired Findling as a public defender 33 years ago.

“I will not be able to sleep at night if during the next twelve months I do nothing to lessen the impact of collateral consequences for the men and women who have been arrested, prosecuted and/or convicted of a crime; especially those who have been sentenced to prison,” Findling said. “I will only be able to sleep better at night after I know I have done something to ease their transition back to society, by helping to restore their right to vote, enhance their opportunity to get jobs that pay living wages and overall reestablish themselves as citizens whose past misdeeds have truly been forgiven and forgotten.”

Drew Findling 84L is due to be sworn in as president of the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers on July 29 in Miami. But last year as president-elect, he let the group know he wanted to focus on how those who have been incarcerated can successfully reenter society.

“The product of that idea is a three-day gathering of defense attorneys, judges, prosecutors, celebrities and former prison inmates in Atlanta Aug. 23-25,” according to the Daily Report. It’s titled: “Shattering the Shackles of Collateral Consequences: Exploring Moral Principles and Economic Innovations to Restore Rights and Opportunities.” Scheduled speakers include: Gov. Nathan Deal, former U.S. Deputy Attorney General Sally Yates, NAACP President Derrick Johnson, Koch Industries GC Mark Holden, and Georgetown law professor Shon Hopwood. Also, in the lineup are actor and comedian Mike Epps, who served prison time as a teenager, along with some of the beneficiaries of pardons and commutations by former U.S. presidents. Read the story.

Read more and register here.

Robin Frazer Clark 88L and Justice Leah Ward Sears 80L were quoted in a Daily Report story published days before the deadline for nominations for two openings on the Georgia Supreme Court. The vacancies were created by two women justices leaving, Katheryn Tucker writes.

“When the new justices are being selected for the Georgia Supreme Court—unless we’re willing, in this day and age, to once again accept an all-male court, which is predominantly white, that neither reflects the diversity of the population served nor that of the legal profession itself—diversity must be a priority rather than an afterthought,” Sears said.

“It is, without question, imperative that our bench reflect the natural and inherent diversity of our beloved state,” Clark said. “When the bench is reflective of our diverse citizenry, there is greater confidence in the court’s rulings. Greater confidence in the bench’s rulings results in greater acceptance of its authority. Greater acceptance of the Court’s authority directly results in appreciation of the Rule of Law. This is a good thing.”

Read the story.

Senior Judge Frank M. Hull 73L, U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit, received the Lifetime Achievement Award this year at the Daily Report’s 2018 Georgia Legal Awards annual ceremony.

“I simply loved being on the State Court of Fulton County, which I still consider my most important challenge and accomplishment, because I tried cases constantly,” she told the newspaper in an interview. “In my view, state courts of our country handle collectively 10 million cases, while all federal district courts had 250,000 total and 60,000 appeals collectively before all federal courts. My most important and favorite job will remain the State Court of Fulton County due to the constant daily interaction with litigants, lawyers and the community. The ‘lower the level’ of the court, the more important the court, as it is where most experience justice or do not.”

Read the story.

Mark Wasserman 86L, U.S. CEO for Eversheds Sutherland, told the Daily Report that the firm’s U.S. branch aims to have women represent at least 30 percent of its total partners and its equity partners by 2021.

“To move the needle, everyone in the firm needs a target,” Wasserman said. “We use metrics in other ways—[that] we want to have revenue of X and work of Y—so why not do so about something as important as our diversity and inclusion numbers?” Read the story.

Amy Weil 81Lhas been invited by the U.S. Supreme Court to brief and argue a specific position in an attorneys’ fee dispute (in a social security case) that will likely be argued next term. Typically, these rare appointments typically go to former high court clerks, Bloomberg Law reports. It’s the first time justices have asked a non-former clerk to argue as an amicus in an upcoming case in over a decade, according to Bloomberg research. There have only been 51 other such appointments since the practice began in 1966, according Adam Feldman, who blogged about the practice in January. Weil was inducted as a fellow of the American Academy of Appellate Lawyers in 2016. Read the story.

Spencer Preis 03L is ethics and compliance officer and chief litigation counsel at Southwire Company, the largest manufacturer of wire and cable products in North America. Its corporate offices are in Carrollton, Ga. His primary responsibilities will be to grow the company’s global ethics and compliance program, and manage the company’s litigation portfolio. Preis was also appointed to the executive committee of Camp Twin Lakes’ Board of Directors. For 25 years, the camp has provided fully adaptive, medically supportive experiences to more than 10,000 of Georgia’s children and young adults. The goal is to help campers grow confidence and experience the joys of childhood.

Dara Mann 96L, known for her national class action, product liability and toxic tort practice has joined Squire Patton Boggs in its new Atlanta office, which it opened in February with a three-partner team from global firm Dentons.

After 22 years in practice, “working consecutively without a real break,” she decided to take a breather and consider her options before ultimately deciding on Squire Patton Boggs, Mann told the Daily Report. “It’s about what I want the future to look like,” she said. “The excitement of helping to develop this office with Squire was the standout to me.”

“Dara is a collaborative person. That’s why we’re so excited to have her,” said Ann-Marie McGaughey, managing partner of the Atlanta office. “In building this office, we really have the chance to build something special, and Dara is a key piece of that.” Read the story.

Joyce B. Klemmer 81L has joined JAMS, an alternative dispute resolution organization. She is based in Atlanta and available worldwide to serve as a mediator, arbitrator, special master and discovery referee in areas including intellectual property, copyright, patent and trademark infringement, trade secrets and related disputes involving contracts and licenses. This follows a three-decade career in intellectual property litigation, most recently as a partner at Smith, Gambrell & Russell LLP.

“Joyce has a well-deserved reputation as a successful and experienced intellectual property attorney and neutral,” said Chris Poole, JAMS president and CEO. “We are excited to have her join the JAMS panel and know that her talent and creativity in settling disputes will be incredibly valuable to attorneys and their clients.” Read the release.

George Choundas 92C 95L has just published another book, a collection of short stories titled The Making Sense of Things. It received the Ronald Sukenick Innovative Fiction Prize, and was shortlisted for the Robert C. Jones Prize for Short Prose, the St. Lawrence Book Award for Fiction, and the Katherine Anne Porter Prize in Short Fiction. Choudas is also author of 2007’s The Pirate Primer: Mastering the Language of Swashbucklers and Rogues. Here’s an interview from last month with Choundas, a litigator and former FBI agent who practices in New York City. His bio from a 2016 Kenyon Review story sums up his work.

Walter Jospin 79L, former regional director of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission in Atlanta, is now of counsel with Finch McCranie. He joins the firm’s whistleblower practice.

“Walter Jospin’s successes as the SEC regional director and his long experience in private practice fit perfectly with Finch McCranie’s white-collar and SEC defense, corporate governance and internal investigations practices,” said former U.S. Deputy Attorney General Larry Thompson. “He will be a tremendous asset to our firm’s clients.”

“I was interested in a law firm with a sophisticated white-collar defense and internal investigations practice,” Jospin said. “I want to work on interesting matters. I like the people here … because they are smart. They do great work.” The firm’s partners all have federal prosecutorial experience. Read the story.

This month, Aloke Chakravarty 97L joined Snell & Wilmer, in the firm’s Denver, Colorado, offices. Chakravarty, the federal prosecutor who prosecuted the Boston Marathon bombing case, joins the firm as a partner and will practice in its White Collar Defense and Investigations group and the Cybersecurity, Data Protection and Privacy practice.

Chakravarty arrives from the U.S. Department of Justice where he prosecuted the U.S. v. Tsarnaev case. He led the crisis response and investigation team minutes after the bombing, developed and presented the case at grand jury, trial and sentencing, and assisted in the appeal. Read the firm release.

John L. Taylor 66Ox 68C 71L passed away on April 22, 2018. An Eagle Scout and later, a Marine, Taylor was a captain in the Office of the Staff Judge Advocate General’s Corps. After his military service, he returned to Atlanta to join Troutman, Sanders, Ashemore & Boozer, and later established his own firm: McDaniel, Chorey & Taylor, now known as Taylor, Feil, Harper, Lumsden & Hess. A litigator with a long list of storied clients, Taylor at one point argued at the U.S. Supreme Court, a case that involved tax law and alcohol regulations. He was also was an avid sailor, cyclist, outdoorsman, and world traveler. In the civic realm, he served as president of the Druid Hills Civic Association, and he and his wife, Susan, helped to establish the Olmstead Park Society. Read the obituary.

In February, Daniel Fliman 03L, one of Turnarounds & Workouts' Outstanding Young Restructuring Lawyers and a Benchmark Litigation Future Star, joined Stroock's Financial Restructuring Group as a partner. He arrives from Kasowitz Benson Torres. His practice includes all aspects of financial restructuring, with an emphasis on strategic litigation. He has been heavily involved in the Puerto Rico Title III proceeding and the Toys "R" Us and Westinghouse chapter 11 cases, and previously had significant roles in the Lehman Brothers, J.Crew, Sabine Oil & Gas and Caesars Entertainment situations.

"Dan Fliman makes us stronger. He is a talented advocate and a skilled tactician who is a great addition to our team," said Kris Hansen, Financial Restructuring Group chair. "Dan adds depth and a recognized brand, especially to our complex litigation offering, and we provide Dan with a multi-talented bench from which to service his growing client base."

Adam M. Freiman 98L has joined WilmerHale as a partner in New York. He brings 20 years of experience in the New York market, having spent the past 10 as a partner at two AmLaw 100 firms.

“Adam has a deep understanding of the emerging company ecosystem and technology market in New York that is a great match for WilmerHale,” said Susan Murley, co-managing partner. “His arrival follows the addition of David Haber in 2017, marking steady and meaningful growth of our Emerging Company Practice in New York. We couldn’t be more pleased to welcome him.” Read the firm release.

Della Wager Wells 86L, a 2018 graduate of Yale’s Berkeley Divinity School, has been appointed as Porter Fellow in Jerusalem for 2018-19. The Fellowship was established to advance the global leadership of students by working at St George’s, living in the interfaith context of Jerusalem, and volunteering at appropriate local agencies including the Jerusalem Peacebuilders organization. Wells is senior counsel at Alston & Bird in Atlanta and New York. She is also a past president of the Emory Law Alumni Board, and served on the Advisory Board.

“Building bridges of prayer, involvement and understanding that strengthen the ministries of Berkeley Divinity School, St. George’s College, and Jerusalem Peacebuilders is the purpose of the Porter Fellowship. Della Wager Wells is an outstanding appointment who will accomplish much and plant the seeds for more,” said the Rev. Canon Nicholas T. Porter, President of the H. Boone and Violet M. Porter Charitable Foundation. Read the release.

Kristin L. Davidson 04L, an assistant federal public defender in San Antonio, Texas, argued before the Supreme Court of the United States on February 21, 2018, representing petitioner Florencio Rosales Mireles.

“In United States v. Olano, this Court held that, under the fourth prong of plain error review, "[t]he Court of Appeals should correct a plain forfeited error affecting substantial rights if the error ‘seriously affect[s] the fairness, integrity, or public reputation of judicial proceedings,” 507 U.S. 725, 736 (1993). To meet that standard, is it necessary, as the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals required, that the error be one that "would shock the conscience of the common man, serve as a powerful indictment against our system of justice, or seriously call into question the competence or integrity of the district judge?"

Read more at ScotusBlog.

Jeff Bjork 98L has joined Latham & Watkins LLP’s Los Angeles office as a partner in the Finance Department. Drawing on his global experience in large-scale reorganizations and insolvencies, he advises clients in distressed situations across a broad range of industries.

He is an accomplished restructuring practitioner, with years of experience representing debtors (public and privately held), distressed investors, sellers and purchasers of financially troubled companies, bond insurers, debt syndicates, and bondholder groups. He also has a successful track record representing bond insurers and other stakeholders in municipal debt restructurings, including through chapter 9 of the United States Bankruptcy Code.

Peter Gilhuly, global co-chair of Latham’s Restructuring, Insolvency & Workouts Practice, said: “Jeff has a multi-faceted practice and is known as a sophisticated national insolvency player. He possesses the experience, skills, and collaborative character that clients seek when they turn to Latham’s top-notch practice.”

Smith Moore Leatherwood LLP has announced its new, all-female class of partners. In Atlanta, that’s Dorothy Cornwell 09L. She is a member of the firm’s health care group and focuses on litigation and regulatory compliance, particularly at the intersection of the health care and health insurance industries. She is an experienced litigator with substantial involvement in life, health and disability litigation.

“It was not until we completed the decision-making process that we realized that our incoming partners this year are all women,” said Julie Theall Earp, managing partner. “Given the number of talented women professionals we have in our ranks, however, this was not a surprise. We celebrate their success.”

In February, the Georgia Asian Pacific American Bar Association established the inaugural Han C. Choi Mentor Award, to honor its past president and board member, Choi, Class of 1993. The award recognizes members of the bar who demonstrate a commitment to mentor next-generation Asian Pacific American attorneys.

The NAPABA Law Foundation also partnered with the Choi Family to create the Han C. Choi Scholarship, which will benefit Asian Pacific American 1L or 2L law students who exhibit academic excellence, social conscience and an interest in APA issues. Special consideration will also be given to applicants who have been adversely affected by cancer (as a survivor, or family member of a victim or survivor). More details at https://www.napabalawfoundation.org

Mark Trigg 86Lhas joined the Atlanta offices of Dentons US, LLP as a partner with the firm's Litigation and Dispute Resolution practice.

Trigg's practice includes commercial litigation; class action defense, including the $1.5 billion defense of the world's largest computer manufacturer; defamation, advertising and media claims; sports and entertainment litigation; real estate disputes; securities litigation, labor and employment litigation, contractual claims, and white collar criminal defense. Trigg is an instructor with Emory Law’s Trial Techniques Program.

"Mark is one of a handful of elite go-to litigators in the Southeast known not only for complex litigation involving corporations, but also for his deft hand with high-profile individuals in government, sports and entertainment," said Sharon Gay, managing partner of the Atlanta office. "We are delighted he's here."

Read the firm release.

“Behind the Trial,” a new podcast from the LA/Silicon Valley firm McKool Smith and Benchmark Litigation, is hosted by Courtland Reichman 95L. It features conversations with some of the country’s most well-regarded trial lawyers, such as David Boies, Elkan Abramowitz, Gary Naftalis and Diane Sullivan.

The first episode is with Evan Chesler of Cravath, who talks about the lessons he learned as a teacher in the Bronx, when he writes his closing arguments, how he still gets nervous before a trial, and what it takes to become a great trial lawyer. Read the firm release.

“For the more than 40 individuals who had the wonderful privilege of serving as law clerks to U.S. District Judge William C. O’Kelley of the Northern District of Georgia over his nearly 47 years on the federal bench, his passing on July 5, 2017, was sudden and unexpected, depriving us of any chance to say goodbye,” the Daily Report story reads. “(The judge had a total of 54 law clerks, five of whom predeceased him.) Following what would have been his 88th birthday this past January 2, we write to remember and honor our former boss, mentor, and friend.”

Read the story. (subscription required)

David S. Hirsch 09L is among five attorneys who were promoted to partner at Hinckley Allen, effective January 1, 2018.

“These talented attorneys represent the best of Hinckley Allen,” said David J. Rubin, managing partner. “We are proud of them for their exceptional legal expertise, strategic business counsel, and commitment to providing value and delivering results for our clients. They represent the future of the firm and it is with great pride that I announce their promotions.” Hirsch is a partner in the Corporate and Business Group and has a broad range of transactional experience. He focuses on all areas of corporate and business law, including mergers and acquisitions, securities, commercial lending, corporate finance, and tax-exempt finance.

Ryan P. Rivera 04L has been elected to equity partner at Hartman Simons & Wood, effective Jan. 1.

“Ryan’s commitment to clients and Hartman Simons made him a natural choice to be promoted,” said Bob Simons, head of the firm’s commercial real estate department. “His hard work, dedication and knowledge of real estate law are an asset to the firm, and we look forward to his continued growth and success in his new role.” Rivera’s commercial real estate experience includes acquisition, disposition, development and lease transactions nationwide. He represents developers and retailers, including small shop, junior anchor and big box national retailers in all types of retail lease transactions. He also represents landlords and tenants in office and industrial leases throughout the United States.

Shawn Kalfus 01L and law partner Matt Stone have left Smith Moore Leatherwood to start their own civil litigation firm, Stone Kalfus LLP. They focus on the defense of catastrophic injury and wrongful death claims, including those stemming from commercial motor vehicle accidents, passenger vehicle accidents, non-emergency medical transportation, products liability, premises liability, and crane and lift accidents. The firm also represents auto dealerships, restaurants, and retail and hospitality entities in general and casualty disputes. The firm is located in midtown Atlanta.

Stone and Kalfus have practiced law together for nearly a decade at Atlanta-area firms, but this is the first independent venture for both. "We decided it was time to control our own destiny, to be able to hire the lawyers and staff we need – when we need them – to best serve our clients," Stone says.

Manuel Burga, former president of Peru’s soccer federation, was the first person to be acquitted among over 40 people and entities in the soccer world who were charged with a scheme to extract hundreds of millions of dollars in bribes and kickbacks. Of those, 24 pleaded guilty. Burga was cleared of a single racketeering conspiracy charge. He was represented by Bruce Udolf 79L. A former prosecutor, Udolf is now president of his own firm, where he concentrates his practice in white-collar criminal defense, investigations and corporate compliance.

Read the USA Today story.

“Domestic violence does not discriminate. It affects people of every age, socioeconomic class, race and education level,” Farley H. Ezekiel 15L writes in the Daily Report. “I learned how hard it is for a victim of domestic violence to get the help they need to escape the abuse. It inspired me to help survivors in the aftermath of violence, so that no one has to be alone while they put their lives back together.” Read the article.

“At Children’s Healthcare of Atlanta’s Egleston, Bill Odom and T. Jackson Bedford [73L] have been making sure Santa visits children there on Christmas for more than two decades,” the Atlanta Journal-Constitution story reads. “They are accompanied by elves and often times at least one more Santa. With as many as 250 children at Egleston on Christmas, each Santa will visit as many as 50 children. Here are stories about these two special men who fill the very big black patent-leather boots of Santa.” Read the story.

Richard K. Hellerman 87L obtained a landmark victory from the Illinois Appellate Court on November 13, 2017. “In affirming a $2.3 million judgment in favor of Hellerman's client, a real estate developer, against a Teamsters Local Union, the Appellate Court held--for the first time in Illinois--that an unincorporated association such as a labor union may be held liable as a successor for a prior union's commercial debts,” Hellerman writes. Both the trial and appellate court held that the successor union was liable for the predecessor union's breach of a commercial lease for office space for the union's members.

Derek Bauer 00L, a partner at Atlanta’s Baker Hostetler, was quoted in the Daily Report on a story about the misdemeanor conviction of journalist Nydia Tisdale. While there is likely “some sense of relief in local newsrooms” that a Dawson County jury acquitted the citizen journalist and videographer of felony obstruction of a law enforcement officer and criminal trespass, there remains “a great deal of concern” over the decision by Northeastern Circuit District Attorney Lee Darragh to prosecute her and the jury’s willingness to convict her for misdemeanor obstruction of a law enforcement officer.

Read the story.

A. Diane Baker 80L has joined MendenFreiman LLP as a partner in its estate planning, trust and estate administration, and business practice areas.
