She has more than three decades of experience working with families to develop personalized wills and estate plans and guiding clients through the complexities of probate and the challenges of estate disputes. Her business law practice includes corporate law, limited liability companies, new business formations, contracts and other general business law matters.

“Diane comes to MendenFreiman with an excellent track record as a leading trusts and estates attorney with a breadth of experience which will expand the firm’s capabilities and be an asset to our existing clients,” said Lawrence “Larry” H. Freiman, managing partner.

Courtney Devon Taylor 08L was celebrated as one of the Philadelphia Business Journal's 2017 "Women of Distinction" at a ceremony held Nov. 16. Taylor is counsel in Schnader Harrison Segal & Lewis LLP’s Litigation Department and vice-chair of the Securities Litigation Practice Group. Her community involvement includes service as chair of the Board of Directors of Directions for Our Youth, Inc., a nonprofit organization that provides out-of-school programming for about 1,500 students, grades K-12.

“Courtney is a role model both within our firm and for the broader community for her professional accomplishments as a litigator and her many contributions as a leader in service,” said Nicholas J. LePore, III, Schnader’s managing partner. “We are fortunate to have her on our team and congratulate her on this well-deserved recognition.”

Chintan Panchal 03L was interviewed by Forbes in October, about the law firm he co-founded in 2010, RPCK Rastegar Panchal. The headline? “This Law Firm Has Helped Deploy Over $500 Million In Impact Investments Worldwide.”

“Founded in 2010, RPCK is a law firm that offers guidance to individuals looking to successfully launch impact-driven businesses and investments,” Julian Mitchell writes. “By developing a qualified team of legal professionals with experience across various financial services categories focused on driving impact-based commerce for companies and investors, their core goal is to facilitate growth within the expanding market while securing success for both sides.”

Read the Forbes story.

David Ross Werner 09L began his new job as director of state and local government relations for Delta Air Lines on Nov. 1. Earlier this year, Werner had been named executive counsel for Gov. Nathan Deal.

“Werner has been an instrumental member of my administration since the 2010 campaign and I’m grateful for his service to our state,” the governor said in a news release. “During his tenure, Werner has demonstrated an unwavering commitment to the well-being of our citizens and his efforts as executive counsel have helped to advance the interests of many Georgians. His knowledge and experience have been assets to the State of Georgia and I wish him the best as he transitions to the private sector.”

Read the Atlanta Journal-Constitution story.

As of Nov. 1, William J. Cooper 95L is a partner with the Houston offices of Sidley Austin LLP, where he will focus on complex capital markets transactions representing both issuers and underwriters on initial public offerings, follow-on equity offerings, traditional private placements, Rule 144A offerings and private investments in public equity. He is experienced with master limited partnerships, including private formation transactions, IPOs, sponsor drop-down transactions and conflicts committee representation.

“Bill is among a highly sought-after team of five partners we’ve added to our Capital Markets and M&A practices, four of whom – David Buck, Jon Daly, Angela Richards and George Vlahakos – will be based in its Houston office, with the remaining partner – Bill Cooper – splitting his time between Houston and Washington, D.C.,” according to the firm release.

Luther Battiste III 74L has been elected vice president of the American Board of Trial Advocates, and thus will become the organization’s first African American president in 2020.

Admitted to ABOTA in 2000, Battiste is currently the organization’s treasurer, a member of the Executive Committee, and chair of the 2017 Leadership Conference. His past positions include service as a member of the National Executive Committee in 2015; president of SEABOTA (2010-2011); co-chair of the Leadership Conference (2013); and as a member of both the National Board of Directors (2005-present) and the South Carolina Executive Committee (2005-present).

ABOTA is an invitation only organization of more than 7,000 members. Battiste is a founding shareholder with Johnson, Toal and Battiste, P.A., in Columbia, S.C. In his spare time, he hosts a local jazz radio show that was featured in Super Lawyers magazine in May 2017.

In its 2018 rankings, Best Lawyers named Suzanne Tucker Plybon 86L as Lawyer of the Year for Trust and Estates Law in metro Atlanta. Lawyer of the Year is the attorney with the highest overall peer-feedback for a specific practice area and geographic region. Only one attorney is recognized as the Lawyer of the Year for each specialty and location.

Plybon, a partner at Arnall Golden Gregory, is vice-chair of the firm’s Private Wealth Practice and co-chair of the firm’s Tax-Exempt and Charitable Organizations Practice. She is also a fellow of the American College of Trust and Estate Counsel. She focuses on complex wealth transfer planning for high-net-worth clients, which includes international estate planning, sophisticated post-mortem planning and administration, business succession planning and charitable planning. She also advises tax-exempt entities.

Read the firm release.

Alexandra “Sachi” Cole 11L has joined Atlanta’s new Penn Law Group, specializing in complex civil litigation. She will focus on product liability, medical malpractice and other cases where people have been harmed by the negligence or carelessness of others. Cole was previously at Parks, Chesin & Walbert, P.C. in Atlanta where she specialized in whistleblower, sexual harassment and pregnancy discrimination suits.

“Too many Georgians have been--and continue to be--seriously harmed both mentally and physically by the actions or negligence of companies, organizations and individuals,” she says. “It’s our goal to offer them the legal remedies they deserve.”

J. Nathanael Watson 08L has joined Stoel Rives LLP as an Of Counsel attorney in the Environment, Land Use and Natural Resources Group in Seattle. Watson was previously employed as a trial attorney for the Environment & Natural Resources Division of the U.S. Department of Justice—from 2009 to 2013 for the division’s Natural Resources Section in Washington, D.C., and from 2014 to 2017 for its Indian Resources Section in Denver, Colo.

“Nate’s background and experiences fit nicely with our strong environment and natural resources litigation practice in Seattle,” said Seattle Office Managing Partner Vanessa Power. “Adding Nate to our team provides our clients another first class resource in the Pacific Northwest, who can serve client needs locally and nationally, across a range of regulatory issues."

Read the firm release.

Justice Leah Ward Sears 80L was interviewed by the National Law Journal on the subject of her recently released biography, Justice Leah Ward Sears: Seizing Serendipity, written by Rebecca Shiver Davis.

“Sears’ openness, as Davis details, is evidenced by long friendships with people across the ideological spectrum. They range from former Atlanta Mayor Andrew Young—also a former congressman, ambassador and civil rights leader—who first made her a city court judge to U.S. Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas, a member of the high court’s conservative wing. Thomas is also a Georgia native,” the article reads. Read the story. (Subscription required)

Julie Fershtman 86L of Foster Swift Collins & Smith, P.C., is listed in The Best Lawyers in America 2018 and in Super Lawyers 2017. Fershtman was recognized for her work in commercial litigation and insurance law and also, civil litigation (defense) For the fifth consecutive year, she has been listed in Michigan Super Lawyers for both the "Top 25 Women Business Lawyers" and the "Top 50 Women Lawyers."

Fershtman is considered one of the nation's leading practitioners in equine law. Her practice for a national clientele includes contract disputes, fraud, association liability, partnership disputes, and personal injury liability. She has also helped draft and advocate for legislation impacting the industry. Her peers selected her to become a Fellow of the American College of Equine Attorneys, one of about 20 lawyers in the country to achieve the distinction.

Erica M. Jackson 09L recently joined K&L Gates LLP as a partner in the firm's Research Triangle Park, N.C., and Charleston, S.C., offices. She is a member of the firm's FDA and Healthcare practice groups. Jackson will focus her practice on FDA regulatory matters, providing strategic counsel to pharmaceutical, medical device, dietary supplement, food, and biotechnology companies, as well as other related health care entities. She will advise clients on issues related to compliance with laws and regulations enforced by the FDA, the DEA, the FTC, the USDA and the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, and state regulatory agencies.

“Our U.S. FDA practice will immediately benefit from Erica’s experience and in-depth knowledge on FDA legal and regulatory issues, particularly in the pharmaceutical and biologic space,” said Mary Beth F. Johnston, an administrative partner of the firm’s Research Triangle Park office.

“Running a race of any distance is challenging, let alone while pushing a wheelchair. But that is what Matt Sours 96L does frequently across the country as a volunteer with the Kyle Pease Foundation,” the Atlanta Business Chronicle reports. “The organization was founded by Brent Pease and his brother Kyle, who has cerebral palsy, to assist people with disabilities in participating in sports. Among KPF's programs is one pairing able-bodied runners with athletes in medically adaptive wheelchairs, conquering 5Ks, marathons and even Ironman races together throughout the country.

"Sours started volunteering with the KPF out of his friendship with the Pease brothers and his interest in combining his own love of running with furthering the organization’s mission." He is a partner in the Real Estate group at Morris, Manning & Martin.

Read the Chronicle story. (subscription required)

Pamela Pettus 91L is the chief executive officer and co-founder of The Gavel LLC, a national legal network designed to streamline the claims defense experience for claims professionals. Pettus brings to the job decades of experience managing all lines of insured and self-insured claims. Her legal knowledge “was essential for her successful transition to her insurance industry career as a claims representative at State Farm Insurance,” according to a release. Pettus has worked in risk management as an adjuster, senior claims representative, claims manager, and director. Her “extensive history as a defense-client positions her to appreciate the needs of attorneys and specialists to be productive and effective,” the release continues.

Shayna M. Steinfeld 86C 90B 90L published Her Story: Lessons in Success From Lawyers Who Live It earlier this year. Steinfeld is a co-editor and author of one of the book’s essays. The collection is “meant to share stories of success, advice, and inspiration to women in the legal workplace.” The book was published by the American Bar Association, litigation section.

Steinfeld is regularly named a “Super Lawyer” and has also been ranked among the top women lawyers in the state. She is board-certified in consumer and business bankruptcy law and has been in practice in Atlanta with her husband, Bruce Steinfeld 88L, a family lawyer and member of the American Academy of Matrimonial Lawyers. They’ve run their firm, Steinfeld & Steinfeld, PC, since 2000 and have three adult sons in their 20s.

Jeffrey M. Williams 81L, a founding and managing partner at Williams Family Law, P.C. is pleased has been named president of the Pennsylvania Chapter of the American Academy of Matrimonial Lawyers.

“Family Law in Pennsylvania continues to evolve and the AAML is committed to ensuring that the law is developed and implemented with integrity and empathy,” Williams said. “I am proud to lead the AAML Pennsylvania chapter and the pre-eminent family law practitioners of which it is comprised, and I thank my colleagues for this great honor.”

Read the firm release.

Elizabeth B. Rose 07L is a founding partner on the all-woman legal team at Caiola & Rose. The firm will focus on serving franchisors, according to a Daily Report story.

Rose joined Slotkin & Caiola two years ago after serving as a law clerk for U.S. Bankruptcy Court Judge Mary Grace Diehl. “They brought on Meredith Barnes, who focuses on transactional and compliance issues, as senior counsel and Brittany Conklin as an associate. Marcy Sperry, a trademark lawyer, joined as of counsel from her own solo practice after 12 years at Womble Bond Dickinson (formerly Womble Carlyle Sandridge & Rice),” the paper reports.

Read the Daily Report story. (subscription required)

Rose joined Slotkin & Caiola two years ago after serving as a law clerk for U.S. Bankruptcy Court Judge Mary Grace Diehl. “They brought on Meredith Barnes, who focuses on transactional and compliance issues, as senior counsel and Brittany Conklin as an associate. Marcy Sperry, a trademark lawyer, joined as of counsel from her own solo practice after 12 years at Womble Bond Dickinson (formerly Womble Carlyle Sandridge & Rice),” the paper reports.

Read the Daily Report story. (subscription required)

Lisa M. Sheppard 86L has agreed to serve as executive director of North Carolina’s Chief Justice's Commission on Professionalism. She will succeed Melvin F. Wright Jr., who recently retired from the position after 17 years.

"I am delighted that Ms. Sheppard has accepted this leadership role," said Chief Justice Martin. "She has demonstrated her commitment to the advancement of professionalism over the years, and I am confident that the skills and experience she brings will help her lead the Commission in its important work."

Immediately prior to accepting this role Sheppard served as vice president, senior compliance manager, at Bank of America in Charlotte. Sheppard has also served as the Chair of the North Carolina Bar Association’s Professionalism Committee since 2013, and was appointed by Chief Justice Martin to serve as a commissioner on the N.C. Commission on the Administration of Law and Justice (NCCALJ).

John M. Nading 03L has been promoted to partner in DLA Piper’s Washington, D.C. office. Nading was among the 46 lawyers promoted to partnership from the firm’s 28 offices in 13 countries. There were 17 new partners in the United States.

Nading is a member of DLA Piper’s Intellectual Property practice, where he works in the areas of trademark and unfair competition, copyright and domain name, and related Internet matters. He focuses on intellectual property litigation in federal court, as well as proceedings before the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office Trademark Trial and Appeal Board.

Read the firm release.

The annual Henry J. Sommer Legal Aid Scholarship goes to Nate Juster 14L, an attorney with the Home Defense Program at Atlanta Legal Aid Society, for his dedication to representing low-income homeowners who are at risk of losing their homes, many of whom were victims of predatory lending or abusive servicing. The National Association of Consumer Bankruptcy Attorneys grants the award. The scholarship will allow Juster to take part in celebrating NACBA’s 25th Anniversary at its annual convention in May.

“We are pleased to provide this esteemed scholarship to Nate. It gives him the opportunity to gain invaluable resources to enhance his profession and the ability to connect with a vast network of consumer bankruptcy attorneys,” said NACBA Executive Director Dan LaBert.

“I am honored to receive a scholarship from NACBA recognizing the importance of legal aid work and the many contributions Henry Sommer made to the practice of bankruptcy law,” Juster said. “I look forward to attending NACBA's Annual Convention, where I hope to meet and learn from other consumer bankruptcy practitioners and develop techniques to help struggling homeowners.”

Kimberli C. Withrow 97L will lead Boyd Collar Nolen & Tuggle’s new office in Gwinett, which the firm says is the county’s first full-service family law firm. Withrow has been with the firm three years and was recently named partner.

“As the need for sound legal advice in the state continues to grow, this new office and the depth of talent brought by Kimberli allow us to better serve our growing client base,” said John L. Collar, managing partner. Withrow has practiced family law for 16 years.

“Having lived in Gwinnett for nearly my entire legal career, I am pleased to offer a wider geographic market presence for Boyd Collar Nolen & Tuggle’s current and future clients,” she says.

Gensburg Calandriello & Kanter, P.C. recently announced the formation of a new bankruptcy practice group to be led by Matthew Gensburg 83L. The firm also changed its name, from the former Dale & Gensburg, P.C.

“In addition to our name change, we also announce the addition of Matt Gensburg as the head of the Bankruptcy, Restructuring and Workouts Practice Group,” said Tony Calandriello. “These important changes position GCK to continue to serve client needs by providing value-driven and responsive legal services throughout the greater Chicago metropolitan area, nationally and on a global basis.”

Lauren Schwartzreich 04L has been selected as a 2017 fellow with the Leadership Council on Legal Diversity. She is a shareholder with Littler.

“Lauren has exceptional client service and leadership skills, and we are proud to have her represent Littler as part of the LCLD Fellows Program,” said Bruce Millman, office managing shareholder of Littler’s New York office.

The fellows program includes relationship-building, in-person training, peer-group projects and extensive contact with LCLD’s top leadership. During the year, fellows train in “the fine points of legal practice, peer-group projects to foster collaboration and build relationships and extensive contact with LCLD’s top leadership, including managing partners and general counsel.”

In March, B-Metro magazine named Sara Ford 84L a “Top Flight Attorney.” Ford is a partner with Lightfoot, Franklin & White LLC. Criteria include education, contribution to professional organizations, community involvement and outstanding client service, according to the Birmingham-based magazine.

“This is a great honor,” said Lightfoot Managing Partner Wynn Shuford. “This recognition speaks to our firm’s commitment to the Birmingham community as well as our dedication to clients across the country.”

Ford’s specialty is complex commercial litigation, ranging from shareholder derivative suits to medical device litigation. Her specialty is complex commercial litigation.

Judge Diane E. Bessen 79C 87L is now chief judge of the State Court of Fulton County. She was appointed to the bench in 2002 by then Gov. Roy Barnes and has run unopposed since. Bessen has been an active adjunct professor since 2008, teaching medical malpractice and pretrial litigation classes. As she recently said in the Daily Report, "When I teach at Emory I tell my class, 'You can't understand how important your reputation is. I may not remember the hundreds of good attorneys who appear before me, but I will remember the one or two who misbehaved.’’

Read the Daily Report story.
